questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding ear wax is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Ear wax, also known as cerumen, is produced by the glands in the external auditory canal skin.

options.label: B
options.text: Excessive ear wax production is not associated with a higher risk of ear infections.

options.label: C
options.text: Cerumen impaction is does not affect hearing.

options.label: D
options.text: Cotton swabs should not be used for routine cleaning of the ear canal.

questions.correct_answer: C. Cerumen impaction is does not affect hearing.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cerumen impaction is does not affect hearing.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cerumen impaction can impair hearing by blocking sound wave transmission in the external auditory canal. Avoid using cotton swabs for ear cleaning to prevent complications like impaction or trauma.
  • ➤ Cerumen impaction can impair hearing by blocking sound wave transmission

questions.text: Match the following
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A4, B2, C1, D3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oral thrush → Candida albicans . Nasal vestibulitis → Staphylococcus aureus . Otomycosis → Aspergillus niger . Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis → Aspergillus fumigatus .
  • ➤ Oral thrush → Candida albicans .
  • ➤ Oral thrush
  • ➤ Nasal vestibulitis → Staphylococcus aureus .
  • ➤ Nasal vestibulitis
  • ➤ Otomycosis → Aspergillus niger .
  • ➤ Otomycosis
  • ➤ Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis → Aspergillus fumigatus .
  • ➤ Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis

questions.text: A patient with post traumatic facial nerve palsy has presented with absent taste sensation on anterior 2/3rd part of his tongue. His stapedial reflex was checked and it was present. Schirmer’s test for lacrimation was done and it was negativities i.e., lacrimation was normal. Most probable site of facial nerve lesion could be at

options.label: A
options.text: Trans labyrinthine portion (the portion of facial nerve lying at the level of inner ear)

options.label: B
options.text: Horizontal portion of facial nerve on the medial wall of middle ear

options.label: C
options.text: Vertical portion of facial nerve on the posterior wall of middle ear

options.label: D
options.text: In the parotid substance where it divides into its 5 terminal branches

questions.correct_answer: C. Vertical portion of facial nerve on the posterior wall of middle ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vertical portion of facial nerve on the posterior wall of middle ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The topographical diagnosis of facial nerve lesions :
  • ➤ topographical diagnosis of facial nerve lesions
  • ➤ Lesion before the geniculate ganglion : Affects lacrimation, taste, and stapedial reflex. Lesion at the horizontal portion : Affects taste and stapedial reflex but not lacrimation. Lesion at the vertical portion : Affects taste but spares lacrimation and stapedial reflex. Lesion at the parotid gland : Causes motor deficits only.
  • ➤ Lesion before the geniculate ganglion : Affects lacrimation, taste, and stapedial reflex.
  • ➤ geniculate ganglion
  • ➤ Lesion at the horizontal portion : Affects taste and stapedial reflex but not lacrimation.
  • ➤ horizontal portion
  • ➤ Lesion at the vertical portion : Affects taste but spares lacrimation and stapedial reflex.
  • ➤ vertical portion
  • ➤ Lesion at the parotid gland : Causes motor deficits only.
  • ➤ parotid gland

questions.text: Sialolithiasis is most common in submandibular gland because?

options.label: A
options.text: Stenson’s duct travels up against the gravity

options.label: B
options.text: Secretions of submandibular gland are watery than other glands.

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sialolithiasis occurs most commonly in the submandibular gland due to the thicker mucinous secretions of the gland and the anatomy of Wharton’s duct , which travels up against gravity, has a longer course, and is more prone to stagnation.
  • ➤ Sialolithiasis occurs most commonly in the submandibular gland
  • ➤ thicker mucinous secretions of the gland
  • ➤ Wharton’s duct

questions.text: Laryngeal paralysis – false statement

options.label: A
options.text: Vocal cord lies in cadaveric position in unilateral superior laryngeal nerve palsy.

options.label: B
options.text: Both vocal cords lie in paramedian position in bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy.

options.label: C
options.text: Emergency tracheostomy is done in bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy.

options.label: D
options.text: Kashima procedure is done in bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy.

questions.correct_answer: A. Vocal cord lies in cadaveric position in unilateral superior laryngeal nerve palsy.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vocal cord lies in cadaveric position in unilateral superior laryngeal nerve palsy.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In unilateral SLN palsy , the vocal cord is bowed , not in the cadaveric position. In bilateral RLN palsy , both vocal cords are in the paramedian position , causing severe airway compromise that may necessitate tracheostomy or surgical lateralization procedures like the Kashima procedure.
  • ➤ In unilateral SLN palsy , the vocal cord is bowed , not in the cadaveric position.
  • ➤ unilateral SLN palsy
  • ➤ bowed
  • ➤ In bilateral RLN palsy , both vocal cords are in the paramedian position , causing severe airway compromise that may necessitate tracheostomy or surgical lateralization procedures like the Kashima procedure.
  • ➤ bilateral RLN palsy
  • ➤ paramedian position

questions.text: A 40-year-old female came with complaints of hardness of hearing in left ear which was gradually progressive. On examination, tympanic membrane was intact but slight haziness was noticed. Rinne was negative on left side and weber lateralised to the left ear. A pure tone audiometry was advised. Which of the following audiogram belongs to the above patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otosclerosis typically causes conductive hearing loss due to stapes fixation. In audiograms: Blue lines represent the left ear; red lines represent the right ear. A gap between air and bone conduction thresholds indicates conductive hearing loss . No gap but shifted thresholds indicate sensorineural hearing loss .
  • ➤ Otosclerosis typically causes conductive hearing loss due to stapes fixation.
  • ➤ Otosclerosis
  • ➤ In audiograms: Blue lines represent the left ear; red lines represent the right ear. A gap between air and bone conduction thresholds indicates conductive hearing loss . No gap but shifted thresholds indicate sensorineural hearing loss .
  • ➤ Blue lines represent the left ear; red lines represent the right ear. A gap between air and bone conduction thresholds indicates conductive hearing loss . No gap but shifted thresholds indicate sensorineural hearing loss .
  • ➤ Blue lines represent the left ear; red lines represent the right ear.
  • ➤ Blue lines
  • ➤ red lines
  • ➤ A gap between air and bone conduction thresholds indicates conductive hearing loss .
  • ➤ gap between air and bone conduction
  • ➤ conductive hearing loss
  • ➤ No gap but shifted thresholds indicate sensorineural hearing loss .
  • ➤ sensorineural hearing loss

questions.text: Match the following
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) A4, B3, C2, D1

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mastoidectomy : Treats chronic otitis media with complications. Stapedotomy : Treats otosclerosis to improve hearing. McGovern Surgery : Corrects choanal atresia in neonates or children. Dohlman Surgery : Addresses Zenker diverticulum causing swallowing difficulties.

  • ➤ Stapedotomy : Treats otosclerosis to improve hearing.
  • ➤ Stapedotomy

  • ➤ McGovern Surgery
  • ➤ choanal atresia
  • ➤ Dohlman Surgery : Addresses Zenker diverticulum causing swallowing difficulties.
  • ➤ Dohlman Surgery
  • ➤ Zenker diverticulum

questions.text: Horizontal linear acceleration of our body movement is sensed by
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Utricle only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Utricle senses horizontal linear acceleration through its macula. Saccule senses vertical linear acceleration through its macula. Semicircular canals detect rotational/angular motion .
  • ➤ Utricle senses horizontal linear acceleration through its macula.
  • ➤ Utricle
  • ➤ horizontal linear acceleration
  • ➤ Saccule senses vertical linear acceleration through its macula.
  • ➤ Saccule
  • ➤ vertical linear acceleration
  • ➤ Semicircular canals detect rotational/angular motion .
  • ➤ Semicircular canals
  • ➤ rotational/angular motion

questions.text: Regarding Greisinger sign, find the false statement:

options.label: D
options.text: Seen as an extracranial complication of CSOM.

questions.correct_answer: D. Seen as an extracranial complication of CSOM.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Seen as an extracranial complication of CSOM.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Griesinger's sign indicates sigmoid sinus thrombosis , which is an intracranial complication of CSOM , characterized by erythema and tenderness over the posterior mastoid area. Recognize the intracranial nature of sigmoid sinus thrombosis to differentiate it from extracranial complications of CSOM.
  • ➤ Griesinger's sign indicates sigmoid sinus thrombosis , which is an intracranial complication of CSOM , characterized by erythema and tenderness over the posterior mastoid area.
  • ➤ Griesinger's sign
  • ➤ sigmoid sinus thrombosis
  • ➤ intracranial complication of CSOM
  • ➤ Recognize the intracranial nature of sigmoid sinus thrombosis to differentiate it from extracranial complications of CSOM.

questions.text: Following is a vestibulotoxic drug:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Streptomycin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Streptomycin is a vestibulotoxic drug used in conditions like Meniere's disease for selective vestibular suppression, while neomycin, kanamycin, and amikacin are primarily cochleotoxic, affecting the hearing structures.
  • ➤ Streptomycin is a vestibulotoxic drug used in conditions like Meniere's disease for selective vestibular suppression, while neomycin, kanamycin, and amikacin are primarily cochleotoxic, affecting the hearing structures.
  • ➤ Streptomycin
  • ➤ neomycin, kanamycin, and amikacin

questions.text: Sequence of angles of head movements turned sequentially stepwise in dix-Hallpike manouevre:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. 45 degree

Explanation:

  • • Explanation: a) 45 degrees → 30 degrees → 90 degrees → 90 degrees: This sequence does not follow the typical steps of the Dix-Hallpike maneuver. The subsequent movements do not align with the standard procedure. This sequence describes the steps in epley maneuver which is therapeutic (dix-hallpike is only diagnostic).
  • • b) 45 degrees → 30 degrees → 45 degrees → 30 degrees: This sequence includes additional head movements not required in the Dix-Hallpike maneuver. It does not follow the standard steps.
  • • b) 45 degrees → 30 degrees → 45 degrees → 30 degrees: This sequence includes additional head movements not required in the Dix-Hallpike maneuver. It does not follow the standard steps.
  • • c) 45 degrees → 30 degrees → 30 degrees → 45 degrees: This sequence also includes additional head movements not required in the Dix-Hallpike maneuver. It does not follow the standard steps.
  • • c) 45 degrees → 30 degrees → 30 degrees → 45 degrees: This sequence also includes additional head movements not required in the Dix-Hallpike maneuver. It does not follow the standard steps.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective: Understand the correct sequence of head movements in the Dix-Hallpike maneuver, which is turning the head 45 degrees to one side in sitting position followed by tilting it downward to 30 degrees in supine position.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis in the picture:

Ans. B) Ranula

options.label: C
options.text: Exposure to hard wood dust causes Squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: False regarding the lesion that arises from the oil can of larynx?

options.label: A
options.text: It is air filled cystic dilatation

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Boyce sign is seen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic dilatation of the laryngeal ventricle. Boyce sign is not seen in laryngocele; it is associated with Zenker’s diverticulum . Surgical excision is the treatment of choice for symptomatic laryngoceles.
  • ➤ Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic dilatation of the laryngeal ventricle.
  • ➤ Laryngocele
  • ➤ Boyce sign is not seen in laryngocele; it is associated with Zenker’s diverticulum .
  • ➤ Boyce sign
  • ➤ Zenker’s diverticulum
  • ➤ Surgical excision is the treatment of choice for symptomatic laryngoceles.
  • ➤ Surgical excision

questions.text: Risk of aspiration is completely absent in
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Unilateral RLN palsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Unilateral RLN palsy poses no risk of aspiration because the SLNs on both sides remain intact , maintaining normal sensory input to the laryngeal inlet and preserving the cough reflex. Conditions affecting both RLN and SLN bilaterally carry the highest risk of aspiration .
  • ➤ Unilateral RLN palsy poses no risk of aspiration because the SLNs on both sides remain intact , maintaining normal sensory input to the laryngeal inlet and preserving the cough reflex.
  • ➤ Unilateral RLN palsy
  • ➤ no risk of aspiration
  • ➤ SLNs on both sides remain intact
  • ➤ Conditions affecting both RLN and SLN bilaterally carry the highest risk of aspiration .
  • ➤ RLN and SLN bilaterally
  • ➤ highest risk of aspiration

questions.text: A child is brought to OPD with complaints of respiratory sounds for 2 years from birth. On examination, you observed it to be inspiratory stridor. Endoscopic image is shown below. What is the next step in the management of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Supraglottoplasty

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Wait and watch. This approach is appropriate for mild cases of laryngomalacia where the symptoms do not significantly impact the child's feeding or growth, and there's an expectation that the condition will improve on its own as the child grows. Since the child has had symptoms for 2 years, this approach might have already been tried, making it less suitable if the symptoms are severe.
  • • Option B. Wait and watch.
  • • Option C. Tracheostomy. This involves creating an opening in the neck to insert a tube into the windpipe, bypassing obstructed upper airways. It's usually considered a last resort for managing severe upper airway obstruction when other treatments are not feasible or have failed, or when long-term ventilation support is needed.
  • • Option C. Tracheostomy.
  • • Option D. Supraglottic resection and anastomosis. This is a more invasive procedure compared to supraglottoplasty and involves resecting part of the supraglottic larynx followed by anastomosis. It's typically reserved for malignant conditions or severe structural abnormalities and would not be the first choice for managing laryngomalacia.
  • • Option D. Supraglottic resection and anastomosis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a child with severe laryngomalacia presenting with persistent inspiratory stridor impacting their well-being, the next step in management is typically supraglottoplasty, after conservative measures have been deemed insufficient.

questions.text: Identify the sign shown in the picture
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Antral sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Holman-Miller sign (Antral sign) represents anterior bowing of the posterior maxillary wall, commonly seen in conditions like juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma . It is an important radiological finding that suggests a space-occupying lesion in the nasopharyngeal region.
  • ➤ The Holman-Miller sign (Antral sign) represents anterior bowing of the posterior maxillary wall, commonly seen in conditions like juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma . It is an important radiological finding that suggests a space-occupying lesion in the nasopharyngeal region.
  • ➤ Holman-Miller sign (Antral sign)
  • ➤ juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

questions.text: A 15-year-old adolescent male presented with repeated episodes of profuse epistaxis and following features were seen (as shown in the pictures). Find the true statement regarding this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Weber-Ferguson incision is used during surgical excision of this tumour.

options.label: B
options.text: Biopsy should be done before performing surgery to know its nature.

options.label: D
options.text: Proptosis can be caused by the extension of this tumour into pterygopalatine fossa.

questions.correct_answer: A. Weber-Ferguson incision is used during surgical excision of this tumour.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Weber-Ferguson incision is used during surgical excision of this tumour.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a vascular tumor affecting adolescent males. Biopsy is contraindicated, and surgical excision may require approaches like the Weber-Ferguson incision for adequate exposure.
  • ➤ Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a vascular tumor affecting adolescent males. Biopsy is contraindicated, and surgical excision may require approaches like the Weber-Ferguson incision for adequate exposure.
  • ➤ Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA)
  • ➤ Weber-Ferguson incision

questions.text: Cart-wheel appearance of tympanic membrane is seen in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute otitis media

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cart-wheel appearance of the tympanic membrane is a hallmark of acute otitis media , resulting from vascular congestion and inflammation in the middle ear.
  • ➤ The cart-wheel appearance of the tympanic membrane is a hallmark of acute otitis media , resulting from vascular congestion and inflammation in the middle ear.
  • ➤ cart-wheel appearance
  • ➤ acute otitis media

questions.text: What is the correct sequence of nuclei that represent waves of BERA sequentially

options.label: A
options.text: Cochlear nucleus ® olivary complex medial ® lateral geniculate body ® inferior colliculus

options.label: B
options.text: Cochlear ® nucleus olivary complex inferior ® lateral lemniscus ® inferior geniculate body

options.label: C
options.text: Cochlear nucleus ® olivary complex superior ® lateral lemniscus ® inferior colliculus

options.label: D
options.text: Cochlear nucleus ® olivary complex lateral ® medial geniculate body ® auditory cortex

questions.correct_answer: C. Cochlear nucleus ® olivary complex superior ® lateral lemniscus ® inferior colliculus
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cochlear nucleus ® olivary complex superior ®lateral lemniscus ® inferior colliculus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ E-COLIMA mnemonic for the auditory pathway: Cochlear nerve → Cochlear nucleus → Superior olivary complex → Lateral lemniscus → Inferior colliculus → Medial geniculate body → Auditory cortex. This sequence is essential for understanding BERA waves and auditory signal conduction.
  • ➤ E-COLIMA mnemonic
  • ➤ Cochlear nerve → Cochlear nucleus → Superior olivary complex → Lateral lemniscus → Inferior colliculus → Medial geniculate body → Auditory cortex.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient presented to an ENT consultant with complaints of right ear discharge for 3 days associated with ear pain, impaired hearing, and a feeling of fullness in the ear. On examination, external auditory canal was found filled with purulent discharge and a soft, irregular reddish mass was also seen. The consultant tried to clear the discharge and somehow managed to visualise the tympanic membrane which was intact. Of course, while attempting aural toileting, there was slight bleed from the ‘soft tissue swelling’ on touch. Find the false statement among the following options regarding the condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Intratympanic steroid injection should never be given in this type of cases.

options.label: B
options.text: Ga-67 scan is done to know the extent of soft tissue involvement.

options.label: C
options.text: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the causative organism.

questions.correct_answer: D. It is a malignant condition.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It is a malignant condition.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Malignant otitis externa is a severe infection caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa , often seen in diabetics. It is not a malignancy but rather an aggressive, potentially life-threatening necrotizing condition that requires prompt treatment and imaging (e.g., Ga-67 scans) for evaluation.
  • ➤ Malignant otitis externa is a severe infection caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa

questions.text: Which one of the following is True regarding inverted papilloma?
questions.correct_answer: A. Tissue grows into the stroma.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tissue grows into the stroma.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that inverted papilloma is characterized by epithelial tissue growing into the stroma , most commonly arises in the middle meatus , and occurs more frequently in older males . Its unique histological growth pattern and potential for malignant transformation make it an important entity in ENT practice.
  • ➤ inverted papilloma is characterized by epithelial tissue growing into the stroma
  • ➤ middle meatus
  • ➤ older males

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with unilateral hardness of hearing and occasional tinnitus. Rinne was negative on affected side and weber also lateralised towards affected side. Cone of light was present. On impedance audiometry, which of the following type of curve is most likely to appear?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type As tympanogram is associated with otosclerosis , indicating reduced compliance due to stiffer ossicular chain mechanics. Conductive hearing loss with intact tympanic membrane and normal Eustachian tube function suggests ossicular involvement.
  • ➤ Type As tympanogram is associated with otosclerosis , indicating reduced compliance due to stiffer ossicular chain mechanics.
  • ➤ Type As tympanogram
  • ➤ otosclerosis
  • ➤ Conductive hearing loss with intact tympanic membrane and normal Eustachian tube function suggests ossicular involvement.

questions.text: Following is not a part of ethmoid bone
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Inferior turbinate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The inferior turbinate is a separate bone and not part of the ethmoid bone, whereas the middle turbinate , lamina papyracea , and supreme turbinate (if present) are all components of the ethmoid bone.

  • ➤ lamina papyracea
  • ➤ supreme turbinate

questions.text: Regarding the drainage of the paranasal sinuses, find the false statement?

options.label: B
options.text: Anterior ethmoid drains into inferior meatus

options.label: C
options.text: Posterior ethmoid drains into superior meatus

questions.correct_answer: B. Anterior ethmoid drains into inferior meatus
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anterior ethmoid drains into inferior meatus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The drainage pathways of the paranasal sinuses:
  • ➤ Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, and anterior ethmoid sinus. Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoid sinus. Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus. Inferior meatus: No sinus drains here; it is the opening site for the nasolacrimal duct.
  • ➤ Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, and anterior ethmoid sinus.
  • ➤ Middle meatus:
  • ➤ Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoid sinus.
  • ➤ Superior meatus:
  • ➤ Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus.
  • ➤ Sphenoethmoidal recess:
  • ➤ Inferior meatus: No sinus drains here; it is the opening site for the nasolacrimal duct.
  • ➤ Inferior meatus:

questions.text: Find the false statement regarding the ossification pattern.

options.label: A
options.text: Corniculate cartilage is of elastic type, it does not undergo ossification.

options.label: B
options.text: Cuneiform cartilage is of hyaline type, it undergoes ossification.

options.label: C
options.text: Arytenoid is of hyaline type, it undergoes ossification.

options.label: D
options.text: Thyroid is of hyaline type, it undergoes ossification.

questions.correct_answer: B. Cuneiform cartilage is of hyaline type, it undergoes ossification.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cuneiform cartilage is of hyaline type, it undergoes ossification.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyaline cartilages (thyroid, cricoid, arytenoid body) undergo ossification with age. Elastic cartilages (epiglottis, corniculate, cuneiform) do not ossify. Cuneiform cartilage is elastic and does not ossify, making this a key point for identifying false statements about ossification.
  • ➤ Hyaline cartilages (thyroid, cricoid, arytenoid body) undergo ossification with age.
  • ➤ Hyaline cartilages
  • ➤ Elastic cartilages (epiglottis, corniculate, cuneiform) do not ossify.
  • ➤ Elastic cartilages
  • ➤ Cuneiform cartilage is elastic and does not ossify, making this a key point for identifying false statements about ossification.
  • ➤ Cuneiform cartilage

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true with respect to the Little's area?

questions.text: Following is not a part of hypopharynx?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Pre-epiglottic space

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A. Post cricoid area: This area is a part of the hypopharynx located just behind the cricoid cartilage of the larynx. It is clinically significant as it is one of the sites where pharyngeal cancers can develop. Thus, this is a part of the hypopharynx.
  • • A. Post cricoid area:
  • • B. Posterior pharyngeal wall: This refers to the back wall of the pharynx that extends vertically from the skull base down to the esophagus. In the context of the hypopharynx, it is specifically the portion of this wall that lies behind the larynx. This area is also prone to pathological changes such as carcinomas. Therefore, it is considered part of the hypopharynx.
  • • B. Posterior pharyngeal wall:
  • • C. Pyriform fossa: These are paired structures on either side of the hypopharynx, shaped somewhat like pears (hence the name 'pyriform'). They are located lateral to the laryngeal opening and serve as channels that help guide food into the esophagus, avoiding the trachea. The pyriform fossae are critical areas for the examination in patients with dysphagia or suspected head and neck cancers. This is definitely a part of the hypopharynx.
  • • C. Pyriform fossa:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypopharynx comprises post-cricoid area, posterior pharyngeal wall, and pyriform fossa, whereas the pre-epiglottic space, part of the larynx, is not included in the hypopharynx.

questions.text: A pre-auricular sinus is a congenital anomaly that presents as a small pit or opening near the external ear. Which of the following statements about pre-auricular sinuses is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Only infected pre-auricular sinuses require surgical excision.

options.label: B
options.text: Pre-auricular sinuses form due to incomplete fusion of 1st and 2nd pharyngeal pouches.

options.label: C
options.text: Pre-auricular sinuses are congenital in origin.

options.label: D
options.text: Most common site is the area anterior to auricle.

questions.correct_answer: B. Pre-auricular sinuses form due to incomplete fusion of 1st and 2nd pharyngeal pouches.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pre-auricular sinuses form due to incomplete fusion of 1st and 2nd pharyngeal pouches.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pre-auricular sinuses are a congenital anomaly caused by improper fusion of the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with itching and discomfort in his right ear for the past week. She is a known diabetic. She uses ear buds regularly for ear cleaning. On examination, a whitish creamy deposit is noticed in the ear canal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A patient presented to an ENT specialist with a complaint of ear block and hardness of hearing. On examination, a hard, impacted wax was present filling the external auditory canal completely. The doctor tried to remove the hard wax with the help of a probe. Suddenly the patient had a feeling of giddiness and weakness. Syncope episode has occurred. Which is the false statement regarding this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue removing the wax by other methods like syringing.

options.label: B
options.text: Syncope is due to stimulation of Vagus nerve branches supplying posterior meatal wall.

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B are true

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and B are false

questions.correct_answer: A. Continue removing the wax by other methods like syringing.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Continue removing the wax by other methods like syringing.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Impacted wax removal can cause a vasovagal reflex due to vagal nerve stimulation , especially when manipulating the posterior meatal wall. Always stabilize the patient after a syncopal episode and avoid continuing the procedure immediately.
  • ➤ Impacted wax removal can cause a vasovagal reflex due to vagal nerve stimulation

questions.text: Which one of the following is True statement:

options.label: B

options.label: C

  • ➤ The handle of the malleus appears foreshortened in cases of a retracted tympanic membrane due to the membrane’s altered orientation.

questions.text: Simultaneous feeding and breathing are possible in an infant because of?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: Find the false statements on Rinne tuning fork test Positive means patient is having sensorineural hearing loss. Negative means conductive deafness. Bone conduction is less than air conduction in case of conductive loss. Positive means there is no hearing loss. Air conduction is more than bone conduction in case of conductive loss.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 3, 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the Rinne test , AC > BC is positive , seen in normal and sensorineural hearing loss. BC > AC is negative , seen in conductive hearing loss. Misinterpretations like "AC > BC in conductive hearing loss" are false and should be avoided.
  • ➤ In the Rinne test , AC > BC is positive , seen in normal and sensorineural hearing loss.
  • ➤ Rinne test
  • ➤ positive
  • ➤ BC > AC is negative , seen in conductive hearing loss.
  • ➤ negative
  • ➤ Misinterpretations like "AC > BC in conductive hearing loss" are false and should be avoided.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child was brought to an ENT consultant. Antenatal history showed that the mother had TORCH infection. Perinatal history revealed that the child was born at 32 weeks of gestational age with only 1.5kg body weight. Immediately after that, he had severe respiratory distress and was kept on a ventilator in an ICU for continuous 5 days. He was also aﬀected with pathological jaundice. On otoscopy, the external auditory canal and tympanic membrane were found to be normal. Impedance audiometry showed A type of curve. What is the next investigation that you prefer to advice to this child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Otoacoustic emissions

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For infants at high risk of hearing loss (e.g., TORCH infections, prematurity, jaundice, ventilator use), newborn hearing screening is crucial. Otoacoustic emissions (OAE) is the preferred first-line investigation for hearing loss in neonates and infants.
  • ➤ For infants at high risk of hearing loss (e.g., TORCH infections, prematurity, jaundice, ventilator use), newborn hearing screening is crucial.
  • ➤ newborn hearing screening
  • ➤ Otoacoustic emissions (OAE) is the preferred first-line investigation for hearing loss in neonates and infants.
  • ➤ Otoacoustic emissions (OAE)

  • ➤ Young syndrome includes infertility due to azoospermia , distinguishing it from Kartagener syndrome.

questions.text: After a road traﬃc accident, a patient presented with watery discharge from l nostril that cannot be sniﬀed back. Find the true statement regarding the condition.

  • ➤ Beta-2 transferrin is a specific diagnostic marker for CSF.

questions.text: In the internal auditory canal, which nerve lies posteroinferiorly

options.label: B
options.text: Nerve concerned with horizontal linear acceleration.

options.label: C
options.text: Nerve concerned with vertical linear acceleration.

questions.correct_answer: C. Nerve concerned with vertical linear acceleration.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nerve concerned with vertical linear acceleration.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The anatomical orientation of the nerves in the internal auditory canal: Anterior inferiorly : Cochlear nerve (hearing). Posterior superiorly : Superior vestibular nerve (horizontal linear acceleration). Posterior inferiorly : Inferior vestibular nerve (vertical linear acceleration). Anterior superiorly : Facial nerve (stapedial reflex).
  • ➤ The anatomical orientation of the nerves in the internal auditory canal: Anterior inferiorly : Cochlear nerve (hearing). Posterior superiorly : Superior vestibular nerve (horizontal linear acceleration). Posterior inferiorly : Inferior vestibular nerve (vertical linear acceleration). Anterior superiorly : Facial nerve (stapedial reflex).
  • ➤ Anterior inferiorly : Cochlear nerve (hearing). Posterior superiorly : Superior vestibular nerve (horizontal linear acceleration). Posterior inferiorly : Inferior vestibular nerve (vertical linear acceleration). Anterior superiorly : Facial nerve (stapedial reflex).
  • ➤ Anterior inferiorly : Cochlear nerve (hearing).
  • ➤ Anterior inferiorly
  • ➤ Posterior superiorly : Superior vestibular nerve (horizontal linear acceleration).
  • ➤ Posterior superiorly
  • ➤ Posterior inferiorly : Inferior vestibular nerve (vertical linear acceleration).
  • ➤ Posterior inferiorly
  • ➤ Anterior superiorly : Facial nerve (stapedial reflex).
  • ➤ Anterior superiorly

  • ➤ Sphenopalatine artery
  • ➤ first artery ligated

questions.text: A housewife presents with complaints of a blocked nose, loss of smell, and dry, greenish crusty nasal discharge. On examination, nasal cavities appear roomy, and turbinates are atrophied. Which of the following surgery cannot be done on this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vidian neurectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vidian neurectomy is performed for vasomotor rhinitis , not for atrophic rhinitis , where surgeries like Young’s operation, Lautenslager’s operation, or Modified Young’s operation are indicated.
  • ➤ Vidian neurectomy is performed for vasomotor rhinitis , not for atrophic rhinitis , where surgeries like Young’s operation, Lautenslager’s operation, or Modified Young’s operation are indicated.
  • ➤ Vidian neurectomy
  • ➤ vasomotor rhinitis
  • ➤ atrophic rhinitis
  • ➤ Young’s operation, Lautenslager’s operation, or Modified Young’s operation

questions.text: An ENT surgeon is examining the nasal cavity of a post septoplasty patient with the help of Thudicum nasal speculum. What is the finding seen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Synechiae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Synechiae is a common finding post-septoplasty, which occurs due to adhesions between the nasal septum and the lateral nasal wall. The Thudicum nasal speculum , a key instrument in nasal examination.
  • ➤ Synechiae is a common finding post-septoplasty, which occurs due to adhesions between the nasal septum and the lateral nasal wall.
  • ➤ Synechiae
  • ➤ The Thudicum nasal speculum , a key instrument in nasal examination.
  • ➤ Thudicum nasal speculum

questions.text: Most common organism that causes otomycosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aspergillus niger

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspergillus niger is the most common causative organism in otomycosis , followed by Aspergillus fumigatus and Candida species.
  • ➤ Aspergillus niger is the most common causative organism in otomycosis , followed by Aspergillus fumigatus and Candida species.
  • ➤ Aspergillus niger
  • ➤ otomycosis
  • ➤ Aspergillus fumigatus
  • ➤ Candida

questions.text: The radiological sign seen here in this image (marked in blue ink arrow) is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Antrochoanal polyp

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dot sign is a radiological hallmark of antrochoanal polyp , which helps differentiate it from other conditions involving the nasopharynx.
  • ➤ Dot sign is a radiological hallmark of antrochoanal polyp , which helps differentiate it from other conditions involving the nasopharynx.
  • ➤ Dot sign
  • ➤ antrochoanal polyp

questions.text: Following sign does not help you in diagnosing CSF rhinorrhoea?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Phelp’s sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Signs helpful in diagnosing CSF rhinorrhoea include: Reservoir sign : CSF collects in sinuses and leaks out when bending forward. Handkerchief sign : Nasal mucus stiffens, but CSF does not. Halo sign : A bloodstain surrounded by a yellow halo indicates CSF. Phelp’s sign is seen in glomus tumors and is unrelated to CSF rhinorrhoea.
  • ➤ Signs helpful in diagnosing CSF rhinorrhoea include: Reservoir sign : CSF collects in sinuses and leaks out when bending forward. Handkerchief sign : Nasal mucus stiffens, but CSF does not. Halo sign : A bloodstain surrounded by a yellow halo indicates CSF.
  • ➤ CSF rhinorrhoea
  • ➤ Reservoir sign : CSF collects in sinuses and leaks out when bending forward. Handkerchief sign : Nasal mucus stiffens, but CSF does not. Halo sign : A bloodstain surrounded by a yellow halo indicates CSF.
  • ➤ Reservoir sign : CSF collects in sinuses and leaks out when bending forward.
  • ➤ Reservoir sign
  • ➤ Handkerchief sign : Nasal mucus stiffens, but CSF does not.
  • ➤ Handkerchief sign
  • ➤ Halo sign : A bloodstain surrounded by a yellow halo indicates CSF.
  • ➤ Halo sign
  • ➤ Phelp’s sign is seen in glomus tumors and is unrelated to CSF rhinorrhoea.
  • ➤ Phelp’s sign
  • ➤ glomus tumors

questions.text: Match the following
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) a2, b3, c1, d4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Genioglossus prevents airway obstruction by maintaining tongue position. Tensor veli palatini opens the Eustachian tube. Posterior cricoarytenoid abducts the vocal cords and is critical for maintaining an open airway. Oblique interarytenoid closes the laryngeal inlet to prevent aspiration.
  • ➤ Genioglossus prevents airway obstruction by maintaining tongue position.
  • ➤ Genioglossus
  • ➤ Tensor veli palatini opens the Eustachian tube.
  • ➤ Tensor veli palatini
  • ➤ Posterior cricoarytenoid abducts the vocal cords and is critical for maintaining an open airway.
  • ➤ Posterior cricoarytenoid
  • ➤ Oblique interarytenoid closes the laryngeal inlet to prevent aspiration.
  • ➤ Oblique interarytenoid

questions.text: X-ray of a supraglottic infective lesion is shown. Which of the following is true regarding the condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Breathing difficulty is seen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Epiglottitis , characterized by the thumbprint sign on lateral neck X-ray , leads to airway obstruction with inspiratory stridor and breathing difficulty . It is most commonly caused by Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) and requires immediate medical attention to prevent life-threatening airway compromise.
  • ➤ Epiglottitis
  • ➤ thumbprint sign on lateral neck X-ray
  • ➤ airway obstruction with inspiratory stridor and breathing difficulty
  • ➤ Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib)

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is responsible for taste sensation in posterior 1/3rd of tongue?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glossopharyngeal nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is responsible for both taste and general sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue .
  • ➤ The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is responsible for both taste and general sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue .
  • ➤ glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX)
  • ➤ taste and general sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue

questions.text: Find the false statement among the following:

options.label: A
options.text: True positive fistula test indicates perilymph fistula.

options.label: B
options.text: False positive fistula test indicates congenital syphilis.

options.label: C
options.text: True negative fistula test indicates late stages of meniere’s disease.

options.label: D
options.text: False negative fistula test indicates dead labyrinth.

questions.correct_answer: C. True negative fistula test indicates late stages of meniere’s disease.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) True negative fistula test indicates late stages of meniere’s disease.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A true positive fistula test indicates a perilymph fistula, while false positives can occur in conditions like congenital syphilis due to stapes hypermobility. True negatives only confirm the absence of a fistula and are unrelated to Meniere’s disease progression.
  • ➤ A true positive fistula test indicates a perilymph fistula, while false positives can occur in conditions like congenital syphilis due to stapes hypermobility. True negatives only confirm the absence of a fistula and are unrelated to Meniere’s disease progression.
  • ➤ true positive fistula test
  • ➤ false positives
  • ➤ True negatives

questions.text: Which of the following scenario causes more amount of hearing loss?
questions.correct_answer: C. Ossicular disruption with intact TM
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ossicular disruption with intact TM

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ossicular disruption with an intact tympanic membrane results in the greatest degree of conductive hearing loss because sound waves cannot propagate to the cochlea. TM perforation or ossicular disruption with perforation allows some sound transmission through alternate pathways, leading to relatively less hearing loss.
  • ➤ Ossicular disruption with an intact tympanic membrane results in the greatest degree of conductive hearing loss because sound waves cannot propagate to the cochlea.
  • ➤ Ossicular disruption with an intact tympanic membrane
  • ➤ TM perforation or ossicular disruption with perforation allows some sound transmission through alternate pathways, leading to relatively less hearing loss.
